content.text: 1 (a) (i) Define power.
(ii) Show that the SI base units of power are \(\mathrm{kg} \mathrm{m}^{2} \mathrm{~s}^{-3}\).
(b) All bodies radiate energy. The power \(P\) radiated by a body is given by
where \(T\) is the thermodynamic temperature of the body,
\(A\) is the surface area of the body
and \(k\) is a constant.
(i) Determine the SI base units of \(k\).
base units
(ii) On Fig. 1.1, sketch the variation with \(T^{2}\) of \(P\). The quantity \(A\) remains constant.
2 A liquid of density \(\rho\) fills a container to a depth \(h\), as shown in Fig. 2.1.
The base of the container has area \(A\).
(a) Derive, from the definitions of pressure and density, the equation
where \(p\) is the pressure exerted by the liquid on the base of the container and \(g\) is the
acceleration of free fall.
(b) A small solid sphere falls with constant velocity through the liquid.
(i) State
1. the names of the three forces acting on the sphere,
2. a word equation that relates the magnitudes of these forces.
(ii) State and explain the changes in energy that occur as the sphere falls.
(c) The liquid in the container is liquid L . Liquid M is now added to the container. The two liquids do not mix. The total depth of the liquids is 0.17 m .
Fig. 2.2 shows how the pressure \(p\) inside the liquids varies with height \(x\) above the base of the container.
Use Fig. 2.2 to
(i) state the value of atmospheric pressure,
atmospheric pressure = Pa
(ii) determine the density of liquid M .
\(density =\)
3 (a) State the principle of conservation of momentum.
(b) Ball A moves with speed \(v\) along a horizontal frictionless surface towards a stationary ball B, as shown in Fig. 3.1.
Ball \(A\) has mass 4.0 kg and ball \(B\) has mass 12 kg .
The balls collide and then move apart as shown in Fig. 3.2.
Ball A has velocity \(6.0 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\) at an angle of \(\theta\) to the direction of its initial path.
Ball B has velocity \(3.5 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\) at an angle of \(30^{\circ}\) to the direction of the initial path of ball A.
(i) By considering the components of momentum at right-angles to the direction of the initial path of ball A, calculate \(\theta\).

\(
\theta=
\) \(\theta=\)
(ii) Use your answer in (i) to show that the initial speed \(v\) of ball A is \(12 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\).
Explain your working.
(iii) By calculation of kinetic energies, state and explain whether the collision is elastic or inelastic.
4 (a) By reference to the direction of propagation of energy, explain what is meant by a longitudinal wave.

(b) A car horn emits a sound wave of frequency 800 Hz . A microphone and a cathode-ray oscilloscope (c.r.o.) are used to analyse the sound wave. The waveform displayed on the c.r.o. screen is shown in Fig. 4.1.
Determine the time-base setting, in \(\mathrm{s} \mathrm{cm}^{-1}\), of the c.r.o.
time-base setting = \(\mathrm{scm}^{-1}\)
(c) The intensity \(I\) of the sound at a distance \(r\) from the car horn in (b) is given by the expression
where \(k\) is a constant.
Fig. 4.2 shows the car in (b) on a road.

An observer stands at point O . Initially the car is parked at point X which is 120 m away from point O . The car then moves directly towards the observer and stops at point Y , a distance of 30 m away from O .
The car horn continuously emits sound when the car is moving between points X and Y .
(i) The sound wave at point O has amplitude \(A_{\mathrm{X}}\) when the car is at X and has amplitude \(A_{\mathrm{Y}}\) when the car is at Y .
Calculate the ratio \(\frac{A_{\mathrm{Y}}}{A_{\mathrm{X}}}\).
\(ratio =\)

(ii) When the car is parked at X , the frequency of the sound from the horn that is detected by the observer is 800 Hz . As the car moves from X to Y , the maximum change in the detected frequency is 16 Hz . The speed of the sound in air is \(330 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\).
Determine, to two significant figures,
1. the minimum wavelength of the sound detected by the observer,
\(wavelength =\)
2. the maximum speed of the car.
\(speed =\) \(\mathrm{ms}^{-1}\)
5 (a) Define electric field strength.
(b) Two parallel metal plates in a vacuum are separated by 0.045 m . A potential difference \(V\) is applied between the plates, as shown in Fig. 5.1.
A proton is initially at rest on the surface of the positive plate. The proton in the uniform electric field takes a time of \(1.5 \times 10^{-7} \mathrm{~s}\) to reach the negative plate.
(i) Show that the acceleration of the proton is \(4.0 \times 10^{12} \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\).
(ii) Calculate the electric force on the proton.
force = N
(iii) Use your answer in (ii) to determine
1. the electric field strength,
\(field strength = ............................................... NCÂ¹ \) 2. the potential difference \(V\) between the plates.
(c) An \(\alpha\) particle is now accelerated between the two metal plates in (b) by the electric field.
Calculate the ratio
\(ratio =\)
6 A filament lamp is rated as \(30 \mathrm{~W}, 120 \mathrm{~V}\). A potential difference of 120 V is applied across the lamp.
(a) For the filament wire of the lamp, calculate
(i) the current,
\(current =\)
(ii) the number of electrons passing a point in 3.0 hours.
\(number =\)
(b) Show that the resistance of the filament wire is \(480 \Omega\).
(c) The filament wire has an uncoiled length of 580 mm and is made of metal. The metal has resistivity \(6.1 \times 10^{-7} \Omega \mathrm{~m}\) at the operating temperature of the lamp.
Calculate the diameter of the wire.
\(diameter =\) \(m \)
(d) The potential difference across the lamp is now reduced. State and explain the effect, if any, on the resistance of the filament wire.
7 (a) A nucleus X decays by emitting a \(\beta^{+}\)particle to form a new nucleus, \({ }_{11}^{23} \mathrm{Na}\).
State the number of nucleons and the number of neutrons in nucleus X .
(b) State one similarity and one difference between a \(\beta^{+}\)particle and a \(\beta^{-}\)particle.
similarity:
difference:
